Award.AwardTitle: PERSIST: Promoting Educational Reform through Strategic Investments in Systemic Transformation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Boise State University's Promoting Educational Reform through Strategic Investments in Systemic Transformation (PERSIST) project is 1) fundamentally changing how foundational STEM courses are taught; 2) applying a change model (Dormant's CACAO Model) to propagate the use of evidence-based instructional practices (EBIP) among STEM faculty, departments, and curricula at Boise State; and 3) assessing the impact of increased use of EBIP on student learning and retention. The project is empowering a six-member Faculty Associates for STEM Transformation (FAST) Team, supported by the campus Center for Teaching and Learning, that is reaching across college and departmental boundaries to provide leadership for implementation of best practice pedagogies in foundational STEM courses (e.g., General Chemistry, Calculus and Pre-calculus, General Physics, lower division Engineering courses, and upper division Geoscience courses). Mathematics, crucial to STEM student success and retention, is an integrated focus in many of the projects. The assessment and evaluation activities are measuring institutional change, supporting pedagogical reform, and driving continuous improvement. The ultimate impact of the project will be increases in STEM majors and bachelor's degrees, including a specific focus on women and other underrepresented groups in STEM, persistence in STEM from first to second year, and a university culture that sustains long-term efforts of continuous improvement in STEM pedagogy. Boise State's PERSIST is providing a testing ground for how to drive institutional change in teaching practices. Ongoing efforts to share the approach and results of PERSIST are informing transformation of STEM teaching and learning locally, regionally, and nationally.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The focus of Boise State University’s Promoting Educational Reform through Strategic Investments in Systemic Transformation (PERSIST) project was to affect institutional changes in science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) teaching and learning by applying a change framework originally developed for business environments. The project achieved change by engaging faculty leaders and administrators at all levels within the institution in developing a cohesive vision for the teaching and learning culture and implementing tailored strategies and resources to support teaching reform. In addition, focusing on departments as the important unit of change within the university allowed the project to leverage the disciplinary social networks within departments to achieve change.  As a result, the project catalyzed the adoption of evidence based instructional practices by faculty across STEM departments, impacting thousands of students. Over 140 STEM faculty participated in professional development opportunities focused on course redesign activities, the development of expertise with specific evidence-based teaching practices, and/or assessment of teaching.  Many faculty saw improvements at the course level after implementing evidence-based practices in their course. Improvements include higher scores on final exams, lower drop, fail, or withdraw rates, and increased student satisfaction and engagement. Further, the project catalyzed greater student persistence throughout the STEM curriculum, an increase in the number of STEM graduates, and broader participation in STEM programs by women and under-represented minorities. Finally, this project influenced organizational structures and the physical learning environments at the institution. For example, efforts supported by this award shifted the classroom design and redesign process across campus to create spaces that facilitate the use of evidence-based teaching practice.

The impact of this award is an increased understanding of the factors that influence institutional transformation in teaching and learning. Specifically, the following strategies were important to the project’s success:  catalyzing conversations within departments about effective teaching, attending to the varied needs of faculty at different stages of adoption, engaging departmental liaisons to create momentum within each department, providing opportunities for disciplinary faculty to collaborate on teaching reform, and providing faculty development support to faculty making changes.  The work completed in this award contributes to advances in knowledge about change in higher education specifically related to the importance of the departmental and campus culture and climate, leadership support, faculty perceptions of factors that impede and promote transformations in teaching and learning, and the power of conversations and collaborations during the change process.

The broader impacts of this work include substantial contributions to the local, regional, and national dialogue around teaching, learning, and student success. This was accomplished through conference proceedings, publications, and a national professional development institute for change agents, hosted by the project. The national event engaged 79 participants from 22 institutions; participation catalyzed many of these institutions to launch STEM reform projects. Further, several products, such as survey instruments and other resources, have been made available to practitioners and researchers engaged in institutional initiatives to increase faculty adoption of evidence based instructional practices or improvements in teaching and learning. Ultimately, the most significant impact of this project is an increase in the adoption of evidence based instructional practices among STEM faculty in higher education, thereby increasing the number and capabilities of students who become scientifically literate professionals who positively contribute to society.
